MAIN ESTIMATES, 1960 (Cont.)


    Head 40 -

    Question again proposed.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not think we should carry on with the debate today without mentioning the fact that we are sitting on a Sunday - a day of rest for the Christians. And that is, in passing, a useful reminder to us that in a multi-racial, multi-cultural and multi-religious society, different cultural, linguistic and religious groups have their different days of rest. It is a tribute to the tolerance, liberal approach, and understanding of one another's peculiar likes and dislikes, standards and patterns of conduct that you, Mr Speaker, Sir, a Christian, have raised no objection to working on Sunday, that our Muslim friends in this House have willingly come to join us in this debate, and our Hindu friends have not raised any protest. I think it augurs well for the work of my colleague, the Minister for Culture, that he, a member of a minority group in Malaya - not even a real Singhalese but a Tamil, an immigrant of Ceylon, who became an immigrant of Malaya - should have been entrusted with the nurturing of a Malayan consciousness and a Malayan culture. Just in case we are

Column: 1086

talking of different things in different languages, I looked up the dictionary which you have kindly placed at our disposal, but which is now under lock and key in the Library, because a few copies have been somewhat too ardently sought after and never re-discovered. I found that the English word "culture" as defined in the Shorter Oxford Dictionary means:

    "Improvement or refinement by education and training. Otherwise the training and refinement of the mind, taste and manners. The condition of being thus trained and refined, the intellectual side of civilisation."

I then looked up the Chinese dictionary that you have provided us with and it says:

    "Wen hwa-ching shen san te wen ming-"

    The Chairman: Order. Actually, of course, the Prime Minister must continue in English. But I permit him to read the extract from the dictionary.

    The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, I was not trying to befog you. All I was trying to do was to make sure that the things that our translators are talking about are the same, and it is translated in Chinese, as I was saying, in exactly identical terms in content. Culture-

    

    The Chairman: Let us have the Mandarin version.

    The Prime Minister: It says: "Wen" means literature; "hwa" means transformation; and it then goes on to elaborate, "ching shen san te" - the spiritual: "wen-ming", i.e. the spiritual side of civilisation. So I think, in English, the definition of the intellectual side of civilisation is fairly akin to the Chinese definition. I looked up Winstedt's English! Malay dictionary and I was greatly disappointed to see that the great authority was wrong. He has got culture as meaning "Bahasa". A primary schoolboy learning Malay with our new language training facilities in the schools will know that "bahasa" does not mean culture. It means language. But obviously dear Sir Richard in the old days believed that culture is equivalent to language.

    But I am happy that I can use this lever to point out that culture, although akin to language, is not the same with

Column: 1087

language. My colleague, the Minister for Health, has brought me what he says is the correct definition of culture, again in Winstedt's, reading "kebudayaan" which I understand is the usual translation given by the Ministry of Culture.

    But one thing sticks out, namely, it is something which is not innate and inborn in a person. One is not born with culture and one is not born with a language. It is not part of the chromosomes and the genes that are transmitted. That is race as distinct from what is learned. The inherent characteristics - the colour of your hair, the colour of your skin, your nose, your eyes and your build; the fact that you have five fingers on each hand - are things which are predetermined. But the kind of person you grow up to be, the kind of society that we make of ourselves collectively, depend basically upon learning - as the words go: "training and refining". We have placed a tremendous emphasis on education because outside the home, outside the automatic learning that takes place when any infant is being reared by the mother and father, there is in the human civilisation, the other factor - the systematic training of our children in schools.

    I would be the first to admit - and I think we should all bear this in mind - that, however much haste we make, we will never be able to produce a Malayan culture in less than one generation. It is unlikely that we could make the Member for Kampong Kembangan think and respond like the Member for Tanglin. They do not think and they do not respond in the same way, because of past training and past refinement. Whilst the Member for Tanglin was taken up with Moral Rearmament - how one should emphasise what is right and what is wrong, and who is right and who is wrong - the Member for Kampong Kembangan is nurtured in a different tradition.

    One of the most graphic memories in my mind was a little court scene in which the witness, a police detective, was giving evidence through a translator, and he said,"...and the bus came to the junction of Joo Chiat Road and Changi Road and they shouted `Allah

Column: 1088

Akbar' as they mounted the bus." So the Judge said, "Oh, what is that?". He said, "My Lord, that means God is great!" But he also said that those two words did not mean just "God is great!" It is also the Muslim battle cry. Just like the Japanese when they say "Banzai!" and they come charging across the field.

    Now that is the problem with our society. Anyone who has had the opportunity of watching mass activity over the last five years cannot but fail to note that the different cultural groups do not necessarily laugh at the same things. They do not cry over the same things. What is considered extremely witty and funny in one sector may be considered a sacrilege in the other. We do not even have absolutely the same standard of right and wrong and of good and bad behaviour. All the non-Muslims and non-Hindus and a good number of non-Buddhists think that it is not correct for a man to have more than one wife. But there are others who think that it is perfectly legitimate and proper and indeed highly desirable to have more than one spouse.

    It is this balancing of the sensitivity of the various cultural groups which is the art of communal harmony through compromise and understanding, which we will have to put up with until such time as in the next generation, if not in one then in two generations, we are able to produce a relatively homogeneous society. Now the Member for Farrer Park quoted me and said: "Yes, that is right. The English-educated were distinct products." When the Member for Farrer Park was in England during the years before the war, he also discovered the same thing - that the Malayan was a distinct product - the English-educated - and so it is. But he is not going to be the final product. Let us face it. He was the product of a particular era. We can cite examples of it throughout the whole of South-East Asia.

    No colony of Britain in the Far East was more anglicised and was more deemed to be stabilised than Ceylon. There was the acme of the British theory of gradualism - the gradual Ceylonisation of the Civil Service, and the gradual

Column: 1089

transfer of power. And no country in South-East Asia today is more in the throes of cultural and linguistic conflicts and religious intolerance than Ceylon. Something has gone wrong there because the veneer was thin. It was wiped out, and stark realities came up from beneath. Once you appeal to your mass base, and your mass base consists of Buddhists, Christians and Hindus or Tamil-speaking or Singhalese-speaking and English-speaking, or Christians and non-Christians, then everybody begins to adjust and make different appeals and shout different slogans.

2.45 p.m.

    Whatever we do, let us be thankful for small mercies: that we have got the Member for Kampong Kembangan who in one of the debates referred to members of the non-Malay race as orang asing - the foreigner. He now admits that we are not orang asing. That is fundamental. It is an admission of basic premises. For it means acceptance - although there is not much in a name - that the Member for Farrer Park is not orang using vis-a-vis the Member for Kampong Kembangan nor I am an orang asing - for otherwise there will be trouble.

    If we start on a major premise, that we are together going to build up something new, something coherent, something which will be part of everyone of us, but not necessarily all of everyone of us, then I say we shall begin the journey, however long and difficult, towards a more stable and a more closely-knit society.

    We shall probably have more of this when we come to debate the next Head namely, that of Education.

    What we are trying to do is not to produce in five years, as the Member for Farrer Park suggests, one culture, because it is not possible. But in five years, we can bring home the lesson that if you shout old slogans, make appeals to instinctive emotional responses of each particular sector of your society, each one shouting a different slogan, pumping in different political and ideological beliefs, then the net result must be absolute chaos.

Column: 1090



    And Malaya - I prefer to talk of Malaya and not of Singapore because in the long run our destinies are settled by what happens in Malaya as a whole - Malaya is unique because of the almost perfect balance of numerical strength between the indigenous people, who have been here a few hundred years longer than anybody else, and the Chinese, with the Indians as a balancing force - 40 odd per cent on each side, balancing with 10 per cent in the middle, and the Ceylonese and the Eurasians and others thrown in. Once the wraps come off, then I say hell would have broken loose. It is our business, as leaders, never to let the wraps come off.

    The Members on the Opposition side, from U.M.N.O., I am glad to say, have taken a sensible approach since the very early days immediately after the elections. This is fundamental and basic. If you have urgent and acute problems pertaining to your community, you settle on the basis of Malayan unity. You do not start shouting slogans in the newspapers because, if the Government retreats in the face of slogan-shouting, that Government must abdicate and give way to anarchy.

    When the Bertha Hertogh prisoners were sentenced to death, it was an emotional issue - and let us not kid ourselves. But if it turned into a political issue, we must fight and stand firm, not on account of the merits, but because no Government, if it intends to govern in a dispassionate and unbiased manner between races, cultural groups and creeds, can retreat in the face of slogan-shouting by communalists. So in our own good time and at the right juncture, we made the right move. That is important.

    Similarly, with regard to our State flag, State anthem, crest and so on. There are certain things over which it would be unwise to beat drums in the open. I ask Members of the Opposition to remember always that they, particularly the U.M.N.O. Members, share as great a responsibility as the Government in seeing that the wraps never come off, and that arguments and differences of opinions are kept within bounds. Once

Column: 1091

appeals are made to the animal instinctive responses of an individual, once battle cries and not arguments are used, then the answer is the gun and no other. That is the case with any Government, but certainly intensely so with this Government. So I hope the Member for Farrer Park, despite his training and refinement of mind to a certain extent on the Western pattern, will not forget that, when we talk of culture here, we talk of the Ministry of Culture with a capital "C", but when we are talking of ourselves, the people, we are talking of culture with a small "c". And it does not help to poke fun at these things and talk of culture with a capital "K", because that leads once more to battle cries, and slogans and not arguments and sanity.

    The Minister for Culture (Mr S. Rajaratnam): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would first like to take up the complaints by the Member for Kampong Kembangan about the reporting of Assembly debates over Radio Singapore's Malay network. He was not satisfied with it, but unfortunately, he was not precise. He did not give specific instances of where he thought Radio Singapore had fallen down on its job. Does he mean that there had been misreporting of what he or his colleagues had said? If that was so, if he could specify instances, I shall certainly look into the matter. But if the charge is that speeches of certain Members have not been as fully reported as they would have liked, then that is a different matter. In fact, I would ask him to consider the problem of having to compress within the space of ten minutes what was said during the course of five and a half hours. Obviously there must be drastic selection, and much of the torrent of oratory must forever be lost to posterity and only a few tinfuls of what was said here could be reproduced over Radio Singapore after the 9.30 p.m. news for the edification of voters in the various constituencies in Singapore.

    

    The Chairman: There is still the Hansard.

Column: 1092



    Mr Rajaratnam: But I think the Member for Kampong Kembangan is more worried about what people hear over Radio Singapore than what people read in the Hansard.

    

    The Chairman: But the Minister was mentioning something about posterity.

    Mr Rajaratnam: Thank you very much, Sir, for your correction, and I shall certainly convey those sentiments to the Member for Kampong Kembangan just in case. In fact, I would like to point out that the problem of trying to compress all these no doubt exhaustive protestations made in this Assembly into a ten-minute commentary is a very difficult task. Not only that, but the report has got to be ready within the course of about an hour. The debate finishes at 8.00 p.m. The reporter has to go to Radio Singapore, and after writing the report he has to put it over the air by 9.30 p.m. So if there has to be selection, obviously the reporter has to leave out certain things which are said here. But if there is misreporting, then I shall certainly be glad to look into the matter.

    Now, I would like to make a few observations on the subject of Malayan culture, about which a great deal was said yesterday and today. One Member of the Opposition asked the Minister for Culture to define the nature and character of the Malayan culture we are proposing to create. I could give a few personal opinions on the subject. No one has the intelligence, the imagination and the breadth of knowledge to indicate precisely what the nature of Malayan culture should be, and what in fact Malayan culture would be like. It is not a matter for any one person to determine, because that will be decided by the people who create the culture - the artists, the dramatists and the painters - and nobody can lay down the law either by administrative actions or by speeches. Therefore, I do not propose here to express my personal views on the matter, since I have already done this elsewhere. If the Member for Kampong Kembangan is interested I can send him a few copies of my talk. But I can tell him the way in which the Government is

Column: 1093

trying to stimulate the growth of a Malayan culture and provide its emotional and cultural base what is called a Malayan consciousness. I can only tell him of some of the ways in which we have attempted to do this during the last six months. I believe that the first step towards the creation of a Malayan consciousness which is necessary to establish a Malayan culture is to create what I would call an awareness of and respect for the cultures of other communities. That is what we mean when we talk about breaking down cultural barriers. Without an awareness of and respect for the cultures of other peoples, there cannot be even the beginning of a Malayan consciousness. I shall only name two ways in which we are trying to do this. One is by breaking down the cultural walls that exist or have existed in Radio Singapore. The Radio is a powerful mass media for influencing people's attitudes and opinions. Hitherto we have had four language sections operating more or less as isolated units. The Chinese section of the Radio catered purely for Chinese tastes, the Malay section for the Malays, and so on. The result was to make the Chinese more Chinese; to encourage them to believe that Radio Singapore was embodied wholly in the Chinese section of Radio Singapore.

3.00 p.m.

    As far as they are concerned, the other programmes do not exist. It is the same with the Indians, the Malays and the English-speaking. What we have done during the last six months was to change this attitude; to get people to realise that Radio Singapore cannot be defined in terms of the particular section of Radio Singapore to which they listen. So today what is happening is that the things that are said to interest only the English-speaking, which are considered interesting only to the English-speaking find their way into other programmes. Malay music, talks about the Malay language and culture, are channelled into the

Column: 1094

English, Indian and Chinese programmes. We hear Chinese music in English programmes. In other words for the first time, radio listeners have become aware of this-that the Chinese programme is not completely Chinese nor is the Malay programme completely Malay, and that the cultural barriers are no longer as precise and as definite as they used to be once upon a time. So very often today when a listener tunes on to the Chinese programme, he is not quite sure whether he is listening to the Chinese programme or the English programme or the Malay programme or Indian programme, because he might tune to the Chinese programme and listen to Malay music or Western music. This is what we mean when we say we are creating an awareness of and respect for other cultures. An interesting thing, Sir, is that this mixing of programmes has not brought forth any indignant protests, primarily I think because we have succeeded in creating a psychological climate favourably disposed towards the sharing of the cultural heritage of other communities. It is no longer an affront to an English-speaking listener to be exposed to what used to be called "native" music. Today, he accepts it. So by gradually exposing one community to the music, talks and discussions of other communities, we first make them aware of the existence of other cultures and then, by prolonged exposure, they will probably begin to appreciate that other cultural communities have a great deal to contribute. In the past, there was contempt on the part of one cultural group towards other cultural groups. The English-educated always thought that the Chinese or the Malay-educated were ignorant and that they had nothing to contribute or anything interesting to say. It was the same with the Chinese and Indians. Today we have talks put over on the Chinese programmes being translated and put over in the English or Malay programmes, so that for the first time, the English-speaking listener says, "Oh, there are Chinese intellectuals who can say interesting things." So thus we create awareness of and respect for other people's culture.

Column: 1095



    Similarly, Sir, the open-air concerts are organised attempts to do more or less the same thing - to bring before very large mass audiences the cultural achievements of other communities. I would like, in this connection, Sir, to pay tribute to the various cultural bodies who have so enthusiastically and generously responded to our call to come forward and help us in this positive and practical step to create a Malayan consciousness. Today, all we have to do, Sir, is to say we are going to put on an Aneka Ragam Ra'ayat somewhere in the City or in the rural area, and immediately hundreds of artistes come forward and say, "We will put up items," normally, for a very nominal fee. In the past these cultural bodies felt they had no status and no recognition; they were not wanted. But today they feel that they are wanted and called upon to participate in a very great task and therefore they come forward generously - sometimes for nothing - to perform at these concerts. That is why we are able to put these concerts on regularly and, as I said earlier on, on a large scale, simply because there are now people who are ready to respond to our call.

    Sir, another way in which we are trying to create a Malayan consciousness is by creating a feeling of identification with Singapore and its people. First, awareness of the other people's cultures, and now identification with Singapore and its people. We must, I believe, create in our people an awareness that they belong to Singapore and that Singapore belongs to them. National Loyalty Week which has just finished was a massive experiment in this direction. The new State flag, the new anthem, the appointment of a Malayan-born Negara were all attempts to create symbols which would facilitate this identification. However, the sense of identification cannot and should not remain purely at the level of symbols. It must be created in a more positive manner by getting people of all classes, creeds and races to co-operate in order to realise the fundamental principle on which the new State of Singapore is founded. National Loyalty

Column: 1096

Week, as I said, Sir, was a massive experiment in co-operation and self-reliance. That experiment, Sir, has been a great success. People of all classes, races and creeds co-operated to make Loyalty Week a week to remember. We decided that much of the work of organising Loyalty Week should not fall on the Government. In fact, the Government should, as far as possible, stay in the background. So much of the work of organising National Loyalty Week was delegated to the people themselves. As a result, we were able to make National Loyalty Week celebrations practically island-wide and sustained. Civil servants, trade unionists, members of political parties, employers, newspapers, cultural organisations, school children, University students, the police, volunteer organisations and many others too numerous to mention were all given specific functions and were all asked to go and organise functions themselves. We involved all sections of the people by inviting them to make their contributions to National Loyalty Week. Again, Sir, I would like, with your permission, to convey the Assembly's gratitude and thanks to all these people for having at so short notice helped to organise successfully so massive an operation. This co-operation of so diverse groups would not have been possible but for one psychological fact - the sense of identification. Somehow these groups forgot that they held different opinions - political, cultural, racial and religious. They had some other link to hold them together, and that link was that they suddenly felt that they were all part of Singapore - as I said, they felt they belonged to Singapore and Singapore belonged to them. That created what we call a sense of identification.

    All these, I admit, Sir, are only the beginnings of a Malayan consciousness. We have still a long way to go before a Malayan consciousness can become second nature - an instinctive feeling among our people. But we believe that we should reach our goal of a Malayan consciousness as quickly as possible. We shall do this by calculated, if you like, conscious, acts which will stimulate this Malayan consciousness,

Column: 1097

make it develop faster. Therefore, we are not concerned with the sceptics outside this Assembly who leer at our efforts, who say that we are trying to create a hot-house Malayan culture, that we are forcing the pace. We are not concerned at all with the leers and jeers of the people who say that we are being very foolish in trying to force the pace. We believe, Sir, that the creation of a Malayan consciousness cannot be left to the ordinary course of events, to nature, or to history - to allow it to develop gradually of its own accord - because this is too important and vital a problem to be left to the hit-and-miss methods of history, or nature, or what you will. We know what happened in Ceylon and India and other countries where the integration of people of various cultures was left to the hit-and-miss methods of history. Certainly we do not wish to see such tragedies envelope this island. Therefore we say quite openly that we shall persist in our efforts to create a Malayan consciousness by deliberate and conscious acts which we think would facilitate or quicken the emergence of a Malayan consciousness - call it national consciousness by planning if you like. We have to do it this way because there is no alternative. Leaving it to the natural course of events means eventually racial conflict and cultural conflict; and carnage and chaos might eventually result from it. May I, Sir, in this connection say that the creation of a Malayan consciousness is not a job for this or that political party, and we have tried as far as possible, during National Loyalty Week, to convey the message that it is not a job for any one political party? It is a job for everybody, every group, every political party and every social and cultural group in this country. We must first accept the premise that it is an act of faith; that a Malayan consciousness is desirable, possible and inevitable. We must accept that premise because, if we do not, then the job of creating a Malayan culture becomes difficult and perhaps might even end not in a Malayan culture

Column: 1098

or Malayan consciousness, but in communal anarchy. Therefore, Sir, on this basic need to create a Malayan culture and in the belief that a Malayan culture is possible, I think we should not have any doubt or any qualms. We should not sit back and say, "Well, this is a job which we cannot accomplish in this generation or the next generation." We must believe we can do it soon and that we can do it by a deliberate act of will.

    Inche Mohd. Ali Bin Alwi (Kampong. Kembangan)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, I rise not in reply, but to give my views concerning the speech made by the Hon. the Prime Minister and also by the Minister for Culture. Frankly what I said yesterday merely concerned one or two things. But the Prime Minister had taken the trouble to go further on the subject of `culture'. I am thankful that the Prime Minister has given a true and clear explanation of `culture' and only time is needed, between this generation and the next, when it will be accomplished to suit our needs. But today, Mr Speaker, I feel fortunate that from the Opposition side here, I can speak my mind freely and that you, Mr Speaker, Sir, as Chairman, have been able to conduct this meeting so capably.

3.15 p.m.

    This also can be considered as one aspect of 'culture' or a chapter of our `culture' which we can put to use to look after matters affecting culture. I am fortunate, Mr Speaker, particularly for being able to express my views. It is hoped that we will be able to accomplish the `Malayan culture' which we are striving to accomplish. Like the Prime Minister, I am also against anything that makes undue appeal to emotion. Therefore, on the question of `culture' the views of the Government are laudable, but because the Prime Minister has stated his views, I would not say that they are correct or incorrect. I wish to assert that my ideology is not communalism, nor do I adopt the attitude of being `anti' other communities. I do not discriminate between Chinese and the Malays. In Singapore we have many organisations. For instance, the Chinese who are in the P.A.P. - we do not consider them as our

Column: 1099

enemies. Nor do we consider as our friends only those who are from the S.P.A. It is not our intention to appeal to communal passions. On the question of ideology we fear that there may be ideologies which are diametrically opposed to that of ours and which some may wish to make the basis of `culture' which we are going to create. What we are against is the Communist ideology. We fear undesirable ideologies being introduced into the creation of a Malayan culture. I welcome the programmes put up by the Ministry of Culture, but what I am not satisfied with, is not with the entire work of Radio Singapore but only with one branch of the Ministry of Culture which deals with giving reports of the sittings of this Assembly over the radio. Normally this is heard at 10.45 p.m. I am not after personal aggrandisement or looking for publicity. The object of my comment is to ensure that as far as possible a true summary of the proceedings in this Assembly is conveyed to the public. I am also a tax-payer. I own a radio and I pay tax for that. If I pay $12 but I do not get a proper account of the Assembly proceedings in the news summary, I will not be satisfied. It is not because my name is not mentioned in the news summary over Radio Singapore that I am commenting on this matter. My attitude on this matter is the same as that of the other tax-payers.

    Apart from this, Mr Speaker, I was also referred to by the Prime Minister in another respect. I do not deny that there is a difference between the Member for Farrer Park and the Member for Kampong Kembangan, that is, myself. But I would like to stress here that I have mixed with people of other races and other classes. For instance, I know how to use chopsticks. I learnt the art for 3½ years during the Japanese occupation when I was an employee at the Japanese Naval Air Force, and my head had to be shaven bald. But this was false culture and we could not accept this. I hope the Government will be cautious in the matter of exercising their authority with respect to 'culture'.

    There is another point on which I wish to criticise the Government. I am not complaining but sometimes I feel offended because I do not quite understand the
